questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 3 days. She describes the discharge as yellow and mucopurulent. She has also noticed vaginal bleeding after sexual activity. She has not had any itching or irritation. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a friable cervix. Urine pregnancy test is negative. A wet mount shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Tzanck smear can be used in the diagnosis of viral infections such as herpes simplex virus and varicella-zoster virus infection. Scrapings from the base of a herpetic lesion typically show multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells). Although genital herpes may manifest with vaginal discharge, the lack of “punched-out” painful lesions and ulcer rules out this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A Gram stain of a cervical swab is used to detect bacterial infections of the cervix. However, it has a relatively low sensitivity and cannot be used to diagnose infection with C. trachomatis, which is an obligate intracellular pathogen and therefore difficult to stain. The test has been widely replaced by more sensitive and specific tests with the ability to diagnose both C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy is commonly used to evaluate cervical abnormalities found on cancer screening tests such as Pap smears. It is not helpful in diagnosing the causal pathogen in patients with cervicitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear is used in screening for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or cervical carcinoma. Advanced cervical cancer can manifest with abnormal cervical discharge and bleeding, as in this patient. However, the acute onset of symptoms and the absence of a visible lesion on pelvic examination make infectious cervicitis more likely. A different test is more appropriate to determine the causal organism. If testing for bacterial cervicitis is negative or the symptoms persist after appropriate therapy, the patient should be evaluated for a possible underlying malignancy.

E) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) of vaginal fluid is the test of choice in the diagnosis of C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae. NAAT provides a rapid result, has a high sensitivity, and can differentiate between C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae infection. It has therefore widely replaced tests such as cultures and Gram staining.
questions.hint: Yellow mucopurulent discharge, bleeding after sexual activity, and a friable cervix on pelvic examination are all suggestive of bacterial cervicitis. The most common causes of bacterial cervicitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. She has not had fever, chills, or abdominal pain. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is sexually active with one male partner and they do not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. There is no uterine or cervical motion tenderness. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet mount preparation of vaginal smear can be used to detect flagellated protozoa characteristic of trichomoniasis and clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). These conditions can cause malodorous vaginal discharge but typically result in an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5). In addition, isolated cervicitis is not a typical manifestation of either of these conditions. A wet mount preparation is unreliable in diagnosing the most common infectious causes of cervicitis because these infections only cause the nonspecific finding of a high leukocyte number on the wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

The amine test (whiff test) is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause malodorous vaginal discharge. However, BV typically manifests with an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5) and a gray or milky rather than mucopurulent discharge. Isolated cervicitis makes BV highly unlikely. The amine test does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine analysis and culture would be the most appropriate initial step if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. This patient presents with cervicitis and does not report features of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain).

D) CORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred modality for diagnosing Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections, which are the most common causes of cervicitis. NAAT can also diagnose certain uncommon causes of acute cervicitis such as trichomoniasis. Patients with confirmed gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichomoniasis should also be screened for HIV and syphilis. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing is indicated during the initial prenatal visit (at approx. 10 weeks' gestation) in all patients < 25 years of age and in patients ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can manifest with vaginal discharge and a normal vaginal pH of 4.0–4.5. The discharge, however, is usually odorless and white, crumbly, and sticky rather than mucopurulent. In addition, features of inflammatory vaginitis (e.g., intense pruritus, vaginal burning, dyspareunia, vulvar and vaginal erythema) are typically present. Isolated cervicitis is not typical of vulvovaginal candidiasis. A KOH preparation does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.
questions.hint: An inflamed, friable cervix with a mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os in a sexually active patient suggests cervicitis.

questions.text: An endocervical swab is performed and nucleic acid amplification testing via polymerase chain reaction is conducted. It is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used in the case of chlamydial infection but the administration of doxycycline during pregnancy is contraindicated because intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in the teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring. Although cefoxitin is effective against N. gonorrhoeae, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need cefoxitin. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for N. gonorrhea infection. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhea and positive for C. trachomatis; ceftriaxone is not the first-line therapy for C. trachomatis.

C) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is very effective against C. trachomatis but the administration of fluoroquinolones is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation due to its potential to cause bone and cartilage damage in the fetus.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin is administered for chlamydial infections in which gonococcal infection is also suspected. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need ceftriaxone. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

E) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydial infection in nonpregnant patients but is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and tooth staining in the child. A single dose of oral azithromycin is the recommended first-line treatment for chlamydial infection in pregnant patients. Expedited partner testing and therapy are also recommended to avoid reinfection. Furthermore, patients and their sexual partners should abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days after treatment initiation.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is a first-line treatment option in nonpregnant women who have an isolated chlamydial infection. Although this patient has tested positive for C. trachomatis, doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has cervicitis caused by C. trachomatis and should be treated with an antibiotic that is approved for use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of 2 weeks of postcoital pain and blood-tinged vaginal discharge. She has been sexually active with one male partner for the past 3 months. They do not use condoms. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that she has been taking for the past 2 years. She states that she takes the medication fairly consistently, but may forget a pill 2–3 days per month. One year ago, her Pap smear was normal. She has not received the HPV vaccine. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is tender to motion on bimanual exam. There is bleeding when the cervix is touched with a cotton swab during speculum exam. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The main clinical features of endometriosis include chronic pelvic pain that worsens just before menstruation, dysmenorrhea, premenstrual, or postmenstrual bleeding, and during sexual intercourse (dyspareunia). While endometriosis can spread to the cervix and cause postcoital bleeding, it is associated with dysmenorrhea and menstrual cycle irregularities and, therefore, unlikely in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Trauma to the cervix can be due to several causes, including insertion of tampons or cervical caps, diaphragms or intrauterine devices, and vigorous sexual intercourse. While cervix trauma also manifests with vaginal bleeding and is often painful, it is not the most common cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg attaches outside of the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tubes. Lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and cervical motion tenderness are common symptoms. Although this patient does not take her oral contraceptive consistently and could be pregnant, vaginal discharge and postcoital pain are indicative of a different cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are benign neoplasms often seen in women with a history of nulliparity and early menarche. Common clinical features include dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, dyspareunia, and palpable, irregular uterine enlargement. In the absence of menstrual cycle irregularities and uterine enlargement, which would have been apparent on physical examination, uterine leiomyomas can be ruled out.

E) INCORRECT:

Breakthrough bleeding is the term for bleeding that occurs mid-cycle, and most commonly occurs in women who use combined oral contraceptives, particularly within the first few months after starting treatment. Since this patient occasionally forgets to take her contraceptive medication, breakthrough bleeding is possible. However, breakthrough bleeding is usually painless and not accompanied by pathological findings on physical examination.

F) INCORRECT:

Although early uterine pregnancy may manifest with slight vaginal bleeding, other typical features (e.g., amenorrhea, nausea/vomiting, breast enlargement, fatigue) are absent in this patient. She also lacks pregnancy-typical changes of the cervix on physical examination, including initial softening, increased blood flow, and production of a clear, viscous mucus. Friability and easy bleeding of the cervix are indicative of a different underlying condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia, also referred to as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, is a precursor to cervical cancer and is strongly associated with HPV infections. Early disease stages are usually asymptomatic, while more advanced disease manifests with abnormal vaginal bleeding (e.g., postcoital bleeding), blood-stained or purulent discharge, and hydronephrosis if tumor growth compresses the ureters. While this patient has an increased risk of contracting HPV (no HPV vaccination, unprotected intercourse with a new partner), the development of cervical dysplasia within a year of her last normal Pap smear is unlikely.

H) CORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of cervicitis. Clinical features of this condition include purulent and/or bloody vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and postcoital bleeding. Bimanual examination typically shows cervical motion tenderness, while pelvic examination reveals an erythematous, edematous, friable cervix that bleeds upon contact. Cervicitis typically manifests without fever or abdominal pain (as opposed to infections with upper reproductive tract involvement such as pelvic inflammatory disease). This patient's history and increased risk of sexually transmitted infections (unprotected intercourse, new sexual partner) make cervicitis due to a chlamydial infection the most likely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Colposcopy view of the ectocervix

The ectocervix is erythematous and there is purulent discharge from the external os.
questions.hint: The cervical motion tenderness and friable cervix in this patient suggest cervicitis.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes reports a 3-day history of vaginal pruritus, increased vaginal discharge, and dysuria. She has not had a urinary tract infection in the past year. She uses intravaginal estriol for atrophic vaginitis.
On examination, she has vulvar erythema and foamy, thick vaginal discharge, with a punctate-appearing cervix. She reports an increase in the amount of drainage and a change in the character of the discharge since her last sexual encounter, approximately 2 months ago.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Perform a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid
Recommend a diagnostic trial of not using the estriol cream

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest infection with Trichomonas vaginalis, a sexually transmitted protozoan parasite that causes 5% to 50% of cases of acute vaginitis.

Infection with T. vaginalis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infection in the United States. Symptoms in women include vaginal discharge, pruritus, vaginal irritation, and a punctate-appearing cervix on examination (known as “strawberry cervix”). Infection with T. vaginalis is best diagnosed by culture or polymerase chain-reaction testing, but the diagnosis can be made by vaginal or cervical fluid microscopy and the presence of motile trichomonads; sensitivity of the wet mount is about 60%.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of vaginitis and foamy vaginal discharge is Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid is not indicated because Trichomonas is a protozoan parasite and grows only in specialized media.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not indicated because this patient has clear physical examination findings consistent with her symptoms of vaginitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring vaginal fluid pH is not specific for Trichomonas because pH is also elevated in bacterial vaginosis. That diagnosis should also be considered in this patient, but the next step in management is the same (wet mount microscopy) with either diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic trial of not using estriol cream is not indicated, as estriol does not typically cause local inflammation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of vaginal discharge. She describes the discharge as yellow and mucopurulent. She has also noticed vaginal bleeding after sexual activity. She has not experienced any itching or irritation. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, her cervix is friable. Urine pregnancy test is negative. A wet mount is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Tzanck smear can be used in the diagnosis of viral infections such as herpes simplex virus and varicella-zoster virus infection. Scrapings from the base of a herpetic lesion typically show multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells). It has therefore widely replaced tests such as cultures and Gram staining.

Key learning point: Nucleic acid amplification testing is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing bacterial cervicitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

D) INCORRECT:

A Gram stain of a cervical swab is used to detect bacterial infections of the cervix. However, it has a relatively low sensitivity and cannot be used to diagnose infection with C. trachomatis, which is an obligate intracellular pathogen and therefore difficult to stain. E) INCORRECT:

However, the acute onset of symptoms and the absence of a visible lesion on pelvic examination make infectious cervicitis more likely. A different test is more appropriate to determine the causal organism. questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of vaginal discharge and dyspareunia. She has had two sexual partners in the past 3 months and inconsistently uses barrier protection. Vital signs are normal. Speculum examination shows mucopurulent endocervical discharge and an erythematous, friable cervix. Bimanual examination shows no cervical motion tenderness or adnexal masses. Wet mount shows 15 WBCs/HPF but no organisms. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Perform cervical culture and defer treatment pending results
Refer to gynecology for colposcopy evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deferring treatment while awaiting test results is inappropriate for patients with risk factors for STIs. Empiric therapy is indicated for those with risk factors, particularly young patients with multiple partners who may have poor follow-up adherence.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have clinical features of pelvic inflammatory disease, such as fever, severe pain, or cervical motion tenderness. The absence of these findings indicates isolated cervicitis rather than pelvic inflammatory disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Mucopurulent discharge and a friable cervix are consistent with bacterial cervicitis rather than a fungal infection. The most common infectious causes of cervicitis are chlamydia and gonorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Gynecology referral for colposcopy is reserved for patients with persistent symptoms after appropriate antibiotic treatment or if no infectious cause is identified after negative testing. Initial management should focus on treating the likely infectious etiology.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has clinical findings consistent with cervicitis (mucopurulent discharge, friable cervix, and > 10 WBCs/HPF on wet mount) and multiple risk factors for sexually transmitted infections, including young age, multiple partners, and inconsistent barrier protection. Both nucleic acid amplification testing and empiric antibiotic therapy are indicated due to the patient's risk factors and concern for potential poor follow-up.
